message: As we begin a new year, I look forward to a new era in leadership. Wishing you a Happy New Year and many blessings in 2017!

Today, the 115th Congress convenes and the real work begins. I’m honored to serve as the Representative for the Fourth District of Oklahoma for another term, and I look forward to a productive year in the U.S. House of Representatives.

Took a few moments to admire the new renovations in the U.S. Capitol. Renovations began in 2014 and just finished a few months ago. 2017 will be an exciting year to visit Washington, D.C. For more information on visiting the Capitol and my D.C. office, please visit: https://cole.house.gov/services/tours-and-tickets

Thank you Secretary Sally Jewell for stopping by my office today. I am grateful for your leadership and your generous support for Native Americans and the state of Oklahoma during your tenure as Secretary of the Interior. Many thanks and my best wishes!

The road to repeal and replace Obamacare begins now. There are many different constructs of a replacement plan that Republicans are considering, but Americans deserve a health care system that is patient centered, market oriented and affordable.

I am extremely honored and humbled to be the recipient of the Distinguished Public Service Award from the Secretary of the Navy, the highest honor a civilian can receive from the Navy. I am proud to serve on the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense and am committed to ensuring that our service members and Department of Defense have adequate resources at all times. Many thanks to Secretary Ray Mabus for this incredible honor and thank you to Rear Admiral Craig Faller and your staff for presenting this award to me. https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-awarded-navy-distinguished-public-service-award

Today we celebrate the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was a true pioneer of justice and an icon of the American civil rights movement. Through his example, he taught Americans that the content of a man’s character is the true measurement of his worth.

This morning I spoke on the House Floor in support of two pieces of legislation that just passed – S. Con. Res. 3 and S. 84. The first bill, S. Con. Res. 3 would provide the blueprint for our nation’s budget for the rest of Fiscal Year 2017 and for Fiscal Year 2018-2026. More importantly, it provides the first step in repealing Obamacare. The second bill, S. 84, would provide the waiver needed for General James Mattis to serve as Secretary of Defense in the Trump Administration – it is required that the Secretary of Defense be seven years removed from military service, while General Mattis is only three years. These two pieces of legislation are crucial for America to go forward and make it great again.

Oklahoma has been hit the hardest by the failures of Obamacare. Our state is an example of what happens when promises are broken, premiums rise and the quality of healthcare declines. Our delegation has been united in the fight to repeal Obamacare, and agree to support a replacement that will benefit Oklahomans and Americans of all ages.

Today we recognize and celebrate the peaceful transition of power, and the beginning of President Donald Trump’s administration. We have a lot of work ahead, but I am looking forward to the leadership and progress under President Trump and Vice President Pence.

Each February, the President presents a budget to Congress to outline the funding levels for the next fiscal year. President Trump is faced with many challenges to balance the budget, but we must work together through this delicate process to ensure our government programs and agencies are funded at their highest efficiency.

I am thrilled that President Trump has taken formal action to recognize the week of January 22nd through January 28th as “National School Choice Week.” As a former educator, allowing parents to have the privilege to choose the appropriate path for their child’s education is fundamental for a child’s growth and for the foundation of their future.

Enjoyed meeting with members of the Oklahoma State School Boards Association. It is important that these leaders have the resources and community support necessary to insure that Oklahoma’s families have access to the best possible education.
Had a busy week in Washington, D.C. meeting with groups from Oklahoma and speaking and meeting with various organizations.
Happy birthday to President Ronald Reagan! Some of my favorite memories and best lessons learned come from my time working for his re-election in Oklahoma.

Had a few American Federation of Government Employees groups stop by this week. I was encouraged by our discussions regarding the legislative priorities for AFGE, and I look forward to continuing working with them.
Enjoyed meeting with this great group of high schoolers from Lawton High School during their Close Up visit to DC!

I, along with many of my colleagues, were shocked one year ago today when the news of Justice Antonin Scalia’s passing broke. It is important that the person filling that vacancy continue Justice Scalia’s legacy of literal interpretation of our laws and Constitutional principles. I believe that Judge Neil Gorsuch is a perfect fit for the continuation of those very values.
Always a pleasure to have members of the Boys and Girls Club from Oklahoma stop by my DC office. Truly enjoyed our discussion regarding the priorities we can work on together!

Social Security faces a major crises – if we don’t act now, the Trust Fund will be completely exhausted by 2034. Without reform, the program will soon not be able to pay its beneficiaries. My latest op-ed in The Ripon Society explores the options that Congress can take to fix Social Security so that it is solvent and available for our children and grandchildren in the years to come.

It is an honor to be the recipient of the Gratitude Award for Alzheimer’s cure advocacy. My family has seen the effects of Alzheimer’s first hand. Finding a cure for this terrible disease is among my highest priorities. I had a great day with the Alzheimer’s Association Advocates at the Oklahoma State Capitol, and thank them for all the hard that they do to bring awareness to Alzheimer’s and the need to find a cure. Alzheimer's Association Oklahoma Chapter

Recently, I had the opportunity to sit down with my good friend, Mark Shriver, for the latest episode of “Cole on Congress.” Mark is the President of Save the Children Action Network and has been at the forefront of ensuring that children have access to a quality education. I’ve always been inspired by his work, and I enjoyed learning a little bit more about his life, his involvement with Save the Children Action Network, and his experience as an author. The full episode is available below, and stay tuned for more shows in the future.

Tonight, President Trump will deliver his Joint Address to Congress. I imagine he will take credit where credit is due – it certainly has been a promising first four weeks of his presidency. Among the many successes that he’s had, there are a few things I hope he will address - how he will allocate his defense budget or will he address the growing problems with entitlement programs? In my latest op-ed in The New York Times, I present my thoughts on the issues that should be on President Trump’s radar, and how we all need to recognize the positive that has come with his administration.

Enjoyed meeting with members from the American Legion Department of Oklahoma. Thank you for stopping by and sharing your legislative priorities with me. I look forward to working with you to ensure that our veterans receive their benefits, and that they are always well taken care of.
NA

Last week, President Trump delivered a powerful and optimistic speech in his joint address to Congress. He outlined a prosperous agenda for our nation’s economy, healthcare and security, and I look forward to working with him in those areas and more.

Last night, Republicans released the new bill to finally replace Obamacare. After seven years of fighting this onerous law, we have taken the first step to creating a system that will work for all Americans with more choices, flexibility and affordability. This is a bill that will put healthcare back into the hands of your doctors, pharmacies and ultimately, you the consumer. To read the bill, please visit: https://housegop.leadpages.co/healthcare/

Always great to meet with the Norman Chamber during their annual fly-in visit to DC. I enjoyed meeting with everyone and discussing the priorities that are important to the Fourth District. Thanks for stopping by!

This week I’ll have the opportunity to review the new healthcare bill when it comes before the Budget Committee. I know it’s not a perfect bill and it won’t be the final bill, but it’s a good first step towards repealing and replacing Obamacare with a healthcare policy that works for all Americans.

Yesterday, I had a chance to join CNN’s Wolf Blitzer to talk about the new healthcare bill. Today, I’ll have a chance to look at it myself during the Budget Committee consideration of the legislation, which can be watched live at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vifhnw0mEe4

Although the weather wasn’t agreeable, it was still quite a busy week in Washington, D.C. It was great to meet with Osage Nation Chief Geoffrey Standing Bear and representatives from the Osage Mineral Councils to discuss the relations between the federal government and the Osage Nation. I had an insightful visit to the Executive Office to share my thoughts on Supreme Court Nominee Neil Gorsuch and how he has been a great asset to tribes across the country. Then, I was honored to welcome actress Jennifer Garner, Dr. Brooks-Gunn of Columbia University, Stephen Dow of CAP Tulsa and Don Millican of the George Kaiser Foundation to the Appropriations subcommittee I chair and hear their testimony on the importance of early childhood education.
Always great to meet with the Oklahoma Bankers Association and provide them an update on what we’re doing up here in DC to help advance their legislative objectives.

In this week's column, I share my thoughts on the recent fight for better healthcare. Although I am disappointed that our first and best chance to repeal Obamacare did not become a reality, I am committed to continue the battle to find a working solution for a quality and affordable healthcare system for all Americans.

Always great to meet with local AIPAC – The American Israel Public Affairs Committee members and discuss how Congress can support their priorities here in the U.S. and in Israel. Thanks for stopping by!

I am so grateful, humbled and honored to be the recipient of Alzheimer's Impact Movement 2017 Humanitarian Award. This is extremely touching for me as someone who has been through the heartbreaking experiences brought on by this disease. It is always a pleasure to meet with Bob Thomas and the Oklahoma chapter, and my deepest thanks for all that you do to advocate for a cure. Fighting Alzheimer’s will always be one of my highest priorities. Alzheimer's Association Alzheimer's Association Oklahoma Chapter
Great to speak with the Oklahoma Youth Expo. I enjoyed our conversation on Oklahoma’s leadership in the agriculture industry. Thanks for having me!
I will be hosting two town hall meetings in April. More information can be found here: https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-announces-april-town-hall-schedule

I applaud President Trump for taking swift action against the atrocities caused by the Assad regime in Syria. Congress owes President Trump our best counsel and our best advice, as to how he should pursue America’s priorities. The best way to do so is for his administration to seek an Authorization for the Use of Military Force and for Congress to give him one.

My office is now accepting entries for the Congressional Art Competition, which is open to all high schoolers in the Fourth District. I’m looking forward to viewing all the great artwork for this year’s competition! More information can be found here: https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/students-invited-enter-2017-congressional-art-competition #FourthDistrictFriday

Had a great town hall meeting yesterday in Chickasha. Thanks to all who attended, and thank you for your questions and conversation. My next town hall meeting will be in Ardmore on April 18th. More information can be found here: https://cole.house.gov/services/town-halls/ardmore-town-hall-meeting

Great to meet with Col. Christopher Hussin, District Commander of U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Tulsa District. Thank you for discussing your priorities with me, and thank you for your leadership here in Oklahoma.

Honored to receive the National Association of Manufacturers Award for Manufacturing Legislative Excellence at the Hitachi Facility in Norman. Hitachi, and other manufacturing companies have contributed enormously to the Oklahoma economy, and I am proud to represent them and their priorities in Congress. National Association of Manufacturers
Wishing you and your family a blessed Easter.

Today, we remember and honor the loved ones we lost 22 years ago in the Oklahoma City bombings. We will forever be grateful for the brave efforts from the first responders, the leadership from government officials and the incredible support from the entire state and country throughout the entire experience. We will continue to pray for the families of those we lost, and we will continue to show strength and resilience as a community, and as Oklahomans.

Had another great town hall meeting in Ardmore this week. Thanks to all who came out, and thanks for all the questions. I truly enjoyed our conversation. I will be hosting more town halls in during the August district work month. Stay tuned for more details.

Thank you, Governor Anoatubby and Superintendent Wright for having me at the Inkana Bridge opening ceremony. This bridge will connect the Chickasaw Cultural Center and the Chickasaw Recreation Center for visitors. I am proud to see the amazing development that has taken place in both areas, and proud to have this national treasure in our backyard. (Pictures courtesy of The Chickasaw Nation.)

Had a wonderful visit to the The University of Oklahoma this week with the Department of Chemistry & Biology and the College of Law. Many thanks to Dr. Rice and his research students for giving me a tour of your lab, and for sharing the great work you are doing as a NIH-funded research program. And many thanks to Professor Sellers at OU Law for inviting me to speak with your students on how Congress and the legislative process can apply to the study of law. #BoomerSooner #FourthDistrictFriday

Thank you to the Oklahoma Chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association for having me at the Memory Gala this past weekend. I am truly honored to be the recipient of the Maureen Reagan Award. I’m proud of the achievements that our community has made in Alzheimer’s advocacy, and I look forward to continuing to be an advocate for those affected by this disease and their families until we find a cure.

ICYMI: Always a pleasure to join C-SPAN Washington Journal to discuss the topics that are driving the news of the day. Thanks to host Greta Brawner for having me, and thank you to all the viewers that tuned in and asked questions.

Was a pleasure to have my friend and colleague Rep. John Moolenaar as a guest for the latest episode of “Cole on Congress.” It was great to discuss spending priorities in Congress, as well as get to know him and the Fourth District of Michigan a little more.

On National Astronaut Day, I’d like to recognize and thank Oklahoma’s own General Tom Stafford. A former Air Force officer, Stafford’s decorated career includes more than 507 hours logged in space and six rendezvous missions, including the Gemini and Apollo space projects. Thank you General Stafford for your incredible service to our nation. I am proud to call you a friend. #NationalAstronautDay

Great to visit with my alma mater, Moore High School yesterday! I enjoyed speaking with these bright students and answering their questions about Congress and some of the issues that face our nation. #FourthDistrictFriday

I was honored to welcome the director of the National Institutes of Health, Francis Collins, and the respective directors of various departments within the NIH, to testify before the Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies appropriations subcommittee this morning. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_B2R7Qx508
Yesterday, I was selected to be inducted into the Oklahoma Hall of Fame. I am grateful and humbled by this incredible honor. http://oklahomahof.com/class-of-2017

I’m deeply disheartened to hear of the senseless terror attack targeted at innocent lives, including children. My prayers are with the friends & families of the victims, and the people of Manchester today.
Great to meet with Yasmina Vinci, the Executive Director of the National Head Start Association to discuss how we can work together to improve education and schools for children across the country.
I was pleased to welcome Education Secretary Betsy DeVos this morning to the Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations Subcommittee to learn more about her vision for education in America.
It was great to meet with Courtney Berry, a student at Oklahoma State University, and the Citizens for Space Exploration to discuss the benefits of space exploration programs. Thanks for stopping by!
On Memorial Day, we honor and remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice to protect our freedoms. We are eternally grateful for their service.

Honored to be a part of Holcim’s ribbon-cutting ceremony last week to celebrate the modernization of their Ada cement plant. The expansion and upgrade will create a 20% increase in their production capacity while simultaneously meeting the highest environmental standards.

Today is the seventy-third anniversary of the D-Day invasion at Normandy, the embodiment of the wartime transatlantic alliance.  In 1984, President Ronald Reagan remarked that the lesson of America’s experience in the World Wars is that “It is better to be here ready to protect the peace, than to take blind shelter across the sea, rushing to respond only after freedom is lost. We've learned that isolationism never was and never will be an acceptable response to tyrannical governments with an expansionist intent.”

Bob Stoops and his entire family are an Oklahoma treasure. The Sooner Nation owes Bob Stoops a debt of gratitude for returning Oklahoma Football to its rightful place among the elite programs in the country. I am proud of his accomplishments on and off the field, and I wish him the best of luck in his next chapter. Boomer Sooner!

Yesterday, the House voted to alter Dodd-Frank and provide regulatory relief to America’s community banks and credit unions. The Financial CHOICE Act will restore common sense to banking regulations which will subsequently accelerate economic opportunities for America’s entrepreneurs and small businesses.

In 1847, the Choctaw Nation recognized the hardships that the Irish nation was facing due to famine and contributed $170 in assistance for food. Now, 170 years later, the Choctaw Nation will travel to Ireland for the dedication of the Kindred Spirits sculpture in Midleton, Co Cork. It is amazing to see these two cultures converge in a show of respect and solidarity for their respective histories.
Happy 93rd birthday to our 41st President, George H.W. Bush!

I’m honored to serve as a co-chair for the Congressional Pre-K Caucus, and I enjoyed the opportunity to discuss the importance of investing in early childhood education. Thank you to all the organizations who attended our briefing, and for all the work that you do to advocate for access to quality education across our nation.

Congratulations to the members of the Oklahoma Ambulance Association who received the American Ambulance Association’s Stars of Life award for outstanding service. It is well deserved, and many, many thanks for your dedication and commitment to serving Oklahoma!
My prayers are with Congressman Steve Scalise, the staff, Capitol Police, and all those affected by this morning's incident.

I’m pleased to announce the confirmed Military Academy nominees from Oklahoma’s Fourth District. These young men and women are outstanding leaders in their communities, and I am confident that they will represent Oklahoma with honor and integrity throughout their military service.

I was honored to meet an incredible football player, Eric LeGrand, yesterday with the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation. It was touching to hear his inspirational comeback from a football-related injury that left him almost immobile. Since then, he has worked hard to be a strong advocate for the mobility-impaired community, as well as maintaining an impressive professional career. Thank you to Eric, his mother Karen and the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation for stopping by!

Congratulations to Laura Rose, the winner of the Congressional Art Competition from Oklahoma’s Fourth District! Her watercolor artwork will be displayed in the Cannon Tunnel to the U.S. Capitol for a year and will be seen by thousands. She is a talented artist and has a bright future ahead! #FourthDistrictFriday

On this Independence Day, we all can reflect on the spirit of our Founding Fathers that is alive and well with our nation today. From our entrepreneurs to our men and women in uniform, our nation has always been great - filled with great people and indomitable patriotism. Happy Independence Day.
My thoughts and prayers are with my friend Congressman Steve Scalise and his family. He’s a fighter and a winner. He needs our prayers and support.
Happy Birthday to our 43rd President, George W. Bush - a good man and a great friend!

I am proud that the Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations Subcommittee bill reflects Americans' priorities, from cancer research to early childhood education. I’m about to chair the markup on the bill, which can be viewed here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ky3rqE7nioY

I just announced my town hall schedule for the month of August. For more information, please visit https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-announces-august-town-hall-schedule. I look forward to our conversation! #FourthDistrictFriday

The FAA has worked well for the United States for more than five decades. It’s a system that has kept our complex airspace safe and efficient. The effort to privatize it would  hurt the operation, financial stability, reliability and security of our skies. Let’s not try to fix something that isn’t broken. https://cole.house.gov/media-center/weekly-columns/if-faa-s-not-broke-don-t-try-fix-it
Many thanks to our DC interns for their hard work and dedication this summer. Best wishes in your next chapter!

It’s been a great first week of the August District Work Month. I enjoyed visiting the INCA RSVP Senior Corps in Ardmore, and it was great to see familiar faces. It was also great to have lunch with the Ardmore Young Professionals group and hear about the good work they are doing in the community. Thanks for having me!

What a great visit to the YMCA Military Welcome Center at Will Rogers Airport. I had the opportunity to meet some of the volunteers and staff that help make this a welcoming retreat for our military service members as they travel. It’s an incredible program, and I’m proud that it gives our military members quality care and attention they deserve.

This past weekend’s events in Charlottesville, Virginia, were tragic and deeply disturbing. Free speech and the right to demonstrate are fundamental American liberties. But racism, neo-Nazism and support for the Ku Klux Klan are never acceptable. In this case, these sentiments led directly to violence, which took the life of an innocent young woman and was indirectly responsible for the deaths of two law enforcement officials, as well as injuries to dozens of innocent people. Such events are never acceptable and ought to be condemned unequivocally by every American.   In the days and weeks ahead, it is my hope that we can reflect and come together as a people, and continue to work to resolve the differences that may divide us. In the interim, we should all mourn for those we have lost, pray for those that are injured and refrain from words or actions that make this difficult situation even more divisive and painful.
Thanks to everyone who joined me at my Ada town hall meeting yesterday. I enjoyed our conversation, and always appreciate hearing your questions and concerns.
NA

Thank you to everyone who joined me the other night at my Norman town hall meeting. I appreciate hearing your concerns and questions regarding the issues that face our country today. My next town hall meeting is today in Midwest City. For more information, please visit: https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-announces-august-town-hall-schedule

Thank you to all that joined me at my Midwest City town hall meeting. And many thanks to Rose State College Professional Training Center for being great hosts. My last town hall of August will be tomorrow in Lawton. More information can be found here:  https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-announces-august-town-hall-schedule

It is heartbreaking to see the devastation that Hurricane Harvey has brought to the Houston area. My thoughts and prayers are with our neighbors in Texas and everyone who has been affected by this storm. Oklahoma is here to help.

The opioid crisis is destroying families and communities across the US. It’s time we recognize it for what it is: an epidemic. From recovery programs to research and prevention, we’ve got to do all that we can to stop it.   https://cole.house.gov/media-center/weekly-columns/opioid-crisis

Today and each day we remember the lives we lost 16 years ago in the World Trade Centers, the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pennsylvania. And we will never forget the incredible bravery and heroism from our first responders that day. Our thoughts and prayers are eternally with them all.
It was an honor to speak with the Marine Corps War College and discuss the priorities that Congress has for our nation’s military. Thank you for the opportunity and I enjoyed meeting you all.
Today, President Trump gave one of the most defining speeches of his presidency. I’m glad he put America’s interests first and reaffirmed our nation as a leader on the global stage.

The University of Oklahoma President David Boren is the most consequential and influential Oklahoman since Robert S. Kerr. He has contributed in countless ways to the wellbeing of the University of Oklahoma, our state and our country. He will be missed, and I wish him well on his retirement!

This week, House Republicans, the Trump Administration and the Senate Finance Committee presented the framework for tax reform. The American taxpayer, our businesses and our economy deserve a more fair and simple system. To read more information and to share your thoughts, please visit: www.fairandsimple.gop

Oklahoma was represented well this week in DC. Thank you to Gene Cormier & the American Association of Classified School Employees, the UCO Student Body representatives and OU Athletic Director Joe Castiglione for stopping by. It was great to spend some time with you all! #FourthDistrictFriday
I am heartbroken over the tragic shooting in Las Vegas. My thoughts & prayers are w/ the victims, families & state of Nevada.
I enjoyed meeting with the Midwest City Chamber to give a legislative update on what’s going on in Congress. Thank you for your time today!
It was great to tour The Boeing Company newest expansion in Oklahoma City today. The facilities house research labs and a new flight simulator. Thanks for having me!

It is always a pleasure to meet with the Moore Chamber of Commerce. I enjoyed giving an update on what’s going on in Washington and catching up with familiar faces. I also had the honor of speaking with the Oklahoma Board of Regents. I look forward to following the great work they do for our state’s colleges and universities.

I had an incredibly moving and touching visit at the Children’s Center Rehabilitation Hospital in Bethany earlier this week. I had the opportunity to take a tour of its new four story expansion and visit with a few of the patients. Many thanks to the dedicated Children’s Center Rehabilitation Hospital staff, Crumpton family and Laylah for a great visit!

It was wonderful to meet with Lisa Hancock, a self-advocate for the Global Down Syndrome Foundation ahead of the Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations Subcommittee hearing on Down Syndrome research today. In the hearing, I was honored to have my colleagues, Representatives Pete Sessions, Rep. Cheri Bustos and Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers testify on their experiences and support for Down Syndrome Research. I am moved by the incredible support the Down Syndrome community has and look forward to ensuring that research on the condition continues with adequate resources.
I am heartbroken over the loss and tragedy in Texas. My prayers are with the families of the victims, the community and the entire state of Texas.

This month we celebrate and reflect on our nation’s Native American heritage. I’ve been honored to represent tribal communities at the federal level, and will always work to ensure that the rights, well-being and culture of our Native citizens and tribes are always protected.
Today we pause to honor the service and sacrifice of every man and women who has worn the uniform of our great nation. We are eternally grateful for their service.

This week, I’m looking forward to finally fixing our tax code 31 years later. As the House considers the The Tax Cuts And Jobs Act (H.R. 1), it’s a relief to know that this bill will bring more than 11,000 new jobs to Oklahoma as well as increase the median household income by $2,241.

A few weeks ago, I had the opportunity to hear Frank Stephens’ testimony during the Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations Subcommittee hearing on Down Syndrome research funding. His story and experience is very moving, and is an example of why medical research funding is so important.
Wishing you and your family a blessed and grateful Thanksgiving.
Great to join C-SPAN’s Washington Journal this morning to discuss tax reform and keeping our government funded and open, as well as taking some questions from viewers across the nation.

Medical research and development at institutions like the CDC and the NIH are crucial to protecting our public health. I am honored to be recognized by the Global Health Technologies Coalition with the Congressional Champion Award for 2017. It is so important that we have leaders engaged in the charge to continue, expand and innovate global health research.
Kate Steinle’s death could have been prevented if the city of San Francisco cooperated with federal immigration officials. The time to reform and enforce our immigration system is now.

It was an honor to have my friend and colleague Rep. Diane Black join me on the latest episode of Cole on Congress. Diane has served as the Chairman of the House Budget Committee GOP and I am proud of the legislative accomplishments we have achieved this year under her leadership.

Today’s vote to overhaul and reform our nation’s broken tax code is historic. It has been 31 years since the American taxpayer has seen a real cut in taxes, and now most Americans will see more money back in their wallets thanks to the system laid out in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Furthermore, this bill allows a significant reduction in taxes for corporations, allowing for economic growth and more job opportunities. Although no tax bill is perfect, I am pleased that the House has passed the Conference Report to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. I will continue to work to improve features that need improvement and I look forward to seeing this legislation reach the President’s desk.  https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-statement-passage-conference-report-hr-1

It was an honor to have my good friend, colleague and Chairman of the House Rules Committee, Pete Sessions, join me for another episode of "Cole on Congress." In this episode, we discuss the important role the Rules Committee serves in passing legislation through the House, Pete's advocacy for the disabled community and many more issues of the day. To watch the full show, please click here: https://youtu.be/g3E2x2ldgO4.
Wishing you and your family a blessed Christmas and Happy Holidays!
